questions.question_text:
You are the Office 365 administrator for a company.
You encounter a problem in your tenant. You launch the Microsoft 365 admin center and select Create a new service request.
You need to get help resolving your problem through the admin center.
Which three actions can you perform from the admin center? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content: Surely this is b c d
I logged in the admin center in my company. There is no MS tech number to call, but you can have the support to email or give you a call. So the answer should be BCD

comments.content: but no option for schedule the call on your preferred time as well!!

but you can google their number as well

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/contact-support-for-business-products?redirectSourcePath=%252fen-us%252farticle%252fContact-Office-365-for-business-support-32a17ca7-6fa0-4870-8a8d-e25ba4ccfd4b&view=o365-worldwide#BKMK_call_support
However, I don’t see the option / preference to ask to contact via email but I do know they do contact via mail.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCD
Correct

comments.content:
Its not A as you don't get the option to 'recieve a Microsoft technical support phone number'
If you select "Phone (Response within 15 mins)" then they call you. But you dont call them. Watch this short video for confirmation
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/get-help-support?view=o365-worldwide

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
First: Use the query text box to type information about your problem and receive links to help documentation.
Second: Contact Support
Preferred contact method:
* Phone (Response within 15 Minutes) [at the moment, depending on demand]
* Schedule a Callback
So ACD
I agree B C D is correct.

Selected Answer: BCD
B C D are the right answerws

Selected Answer: BCD
C is self service option in case if its known issue with a known solution. Sometimes it even gives script to fix

B & D would appear once you are ready to submit the request in preferences that you want to be called or emailed by support.

Premier support used to have toll free years back but not anymore. Suprising Microsoft doesn't has a chat with support option so far.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/business-video/get-help-support?view=o365-worldwide

Watch the video and you'll get the answers as BCD

B C D 
https://www.enjoysharepoint.com/create-new-service-request-office-365/#:~:text=Microsoft%20has%20provided%20this%20option%20inside%20the%20Microsoft,Office%20365%20team%20via%20phone%2C%20simply%20dial%201-800-865-9408.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/business-video/get-help-support?view=o365-worldwide ACD is right

B, C and D
Preferred contact methods are Phone, Email and Schedule a Callback. No chat available.
Plus you can get help documentation by describing the issue.

I can see its A,B, C 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/admin-overview/about-the-admin-center?view=o365-worldwide
- i don't see option you can schedule time with Microsoft engineer
- no option from Admin center to get Tech engineer number to call
Sorry is A,B,C
Correct B,C,D
I will stick with ACD
ABC, you cannot schedule a time for an engineer to call and there is no chat service

comments.content: when I worked at a recent position, I specifically remember not being able to schedule a call back from support, they call at random. I also do not remember an option to use chat.

D is correct as you do have the option to schedule a time for a MS technician to call you. For the other option, the query tool is another correct one and you can find a regional phone number to call MS support. So I would go for ACD

pls read ques carefully.. You need to get help resolving your problem through the admin center.

You don't need to go to another tab while working on admin center to get help

discussion.content: I think this is a bit vague, and even the support documentation is not crystal clear. However, here is a link to Microsoft 365 Admin Center Help: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/admin/manage/message-center?view=o365-worldwide
B, C, D
Definitely BCD - calling would be if there was a Microsoft Premier support agreement signed

comments.content: According to the video they call back with in 1 hour (but is that 'scheduling' a callback?
No time to schedule a call, they call back at random

discussion.content: BCD is correct. However I did not see the provision to schedule the time of the call. It just confirms your phone number. No place to provide time.
A, C and E.. That's what I think.
ACD -> i cannot find any info about MS contacting you via email...

comments.content: Your email address is prepopulated in the request. You can also schedule a call back. You cannot get a phone number from the Admin Center. You cannot start a chat. Answer is BCD.

discussion.content: i think B C D
BCD is correct
BCD I think so too

choices.A: Receive a Microsoft technical support phone number to speak with a Microsoft support technician.
choices.C: Use the query text box to type information about your problem and receive links to help documentation.
choices.D: Schedule a time for a Microsoft service technician to call you.
choices.E: Chat with a live Microsoft service engineer.
choices.B: Request a Microsoft service technician to contact you by using email.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
An organization migrates to Microsoft 365. The company has an on-premises infrastructure that includes Exchange Server and Active Directory Domain Services.
Client devices run Windows 7.
You need to determine which products require the purchase of Microsoft 365 licenses for new employees.
Which product licenses should the company purchase? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content: Are you sure?

discussion.content:
Frustrated to see wrong answers for what I paid for! answer should be
NR
NR
R
NR

I'm not really sure what they're asking here, but...

Assuming they want to install Office apps to their devices, they would need licenses for Windows 10 Pro, since Office 365 Apps no longer support Windows 7 officially.

I don't think they'd need Office Professional anymore since they'd have Office 365.

If they already have Windows Server with ADDS, they don't need a NEW license for compatibility with Windows 10 devices and Azure AD Connect, even if it's as old as Server 2012, it's compatible and it's a perpetual license. If they want to move to Azure though, they'd either need a new license, or they could do Hybrid Benefit and use their existing license. Not enough info for this question, imo.

Presumably they would just use Exchange Online now as it's included in 365.


So I say:

Windows 10 Pro = Required
Office Professional = Not required
Server = ??? Gonna say Required because they're migrating to the cloud and their other devices being Windows 7 probably means they need a new Server license by now.
Exchange Client = Not required

I'll probably change my mind next time I see this question though!

comments.content:
Oops, as predicted I've changed my answer. Windows 10 Enterprise is included with Enterprise plans, E3 E5 and F3. So Windows 10 Pro is not required.

file:///C:/Users/lowe_/AppData/Local/Temp/Modern%20Work%20Plan%20Comparison%20-%20Enterprise%20US%20ERP%20(20).pdf
This comment gave me a cancer xD How you could even go for the exam if you are linking document from your own pc ahha :D

discussion.content:
Win 10 pro required because MS365 is win 10 enterprise but from 7 to 10 pro would require a license
Office not required since O365 is under MS365
Server required because it is not under ms365
Exchange client not required since ms365 has exchange

I think am onto something here with "You need to determine which products require the purchase of Microsoft 365 licenses for new employees." They are mentioning for what services, which they had before, a license is required for new employees. What bothers me is the WIndows 10 pro Upgrade choice. They need a license from an E3 subscription which will include all they need I think. So I don't know what this means but I'll just go guessing. However, am not convinced this question would come up

This is my take on this and is not better than any of the one ones. Let's concentrate with the words "new employees". Why would a new employee need a Windows Update license, he gets a M365 license automatically also Office, so Office Professional goes in the bin.
What I can't be sure whether new users need a license for the Exchange server but I guess they need an Exchange access license. For me it would be a No / No / Maybe /Yes

It's poorly worded but and its not written consistently, but i think its asking will a microsoft licence be required to upgrade this into an O365 environment.

Windows 10 Pro - not required, its a standalone upgrade licence
Office Professional to O365 - Required O365 licence
Windows Server to Sharepoint - Required O365 licence
Exchange to Exchange Online - Required O365 licence

Its just a mess.
Only Windows 10 is required
This is too much confussion, I am going for the answers they gave me.

"which products require the purchase of Microsoft 365 licenses"
w10 pro -NR , R,R,R
The default answers given here are CORRECT.

Q1 - NO https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/business-premium/microsoft-365-business-faqs?view=o365-worldwide#what-is-windows-10-business

If you have devices that are licensed for Windows 7, 8, and 8.1 Professional, Microsoft 365 Business Premium provides an upgrade to Windows 10 Pro, which is the prerequisite for deploying Windows 10 Business.

As the company has Win7, they must be on Pro version.

Q2 - NO, the M365 subscription will include Office services (as not determined exactly, what Office products are needed, as Exchange exist, we can suppose, Outlook)

Q3 - NO, the on-prem servers are already licensed, Azure AD Connect will do the job and can be installed on the DC, or on the freed up Exchange server (which was already licensed)

Q4 - YES, as M365 is per user licensed (migration is planned, so we can suppose the old Exchange will be replaced with Exchange Online)

After looking at this question one more time I think that only required is Windows 10 Upgrade license. Because you cannot upgrade windows 7 with Microsoft 365 license. You need to upgrade to windows 10 first to be able to use Office apps etc..
I can say that I don't understand the question at all. Only way would be to guess the answers. Why we get this crap of questions MS. This is crazy.

Absolutely confusing question. I think there are mistakes in the question area and in the answer area.
First question is asking what Microsoft 365 licenses need to be purchased. The second one is asking what product licenses need to be purchased: "You need to determine which products require the purchase of Microsoft 365 licenses for new employees.
Which product licenses should the company purchase?"
I think we need to consider the product licenses. Because those products cannot require W365 licenses. In this case it will be more or less clear.
1. Windows upgrade is not required to purchase as Win10 is part of W365
2. Office professional. Required as it is not part of W365.
3. Windows server. Not required as we talk about users. If it would ask for Windows server CAL, then required for on-premise environment. So probably there is an error in the answer area.
4. Exchange CAL. Required for on-premise environment.

they are asking "You need to determine which products require the purchase of Microsoft 365 licenses for new employees".
This means:
Does Win 10 require a M365 license? No
Does Office Professional require a M365 license? No
Does Windows Server require a M365 license? No
Does Exchange client Access require a M365 license? No

comments.content:
my vote is Windows 10 NR
all the others required.

discussion.content: The question is "You need to determine which products require the purchase of Microsoft 365 licenses for new employees" So...Windows 10 does not require 365. Yes 365 needs windows 10, but that is not what they're asking. They're asking it the other way around. What requires 365, not what does 365 require. After all I can have Windows 10 without 365. Look at the question very carefully.
more than 10 people commented on answer but can not concludes which answers are correct

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/enterprise/client-server-software-roadmap-microsoft-365?view=o365-worldwide#result

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/downloads/office2010windows7endofsupport.pdf?view=o365-worldwide

I would say: 
Windows 10 Pro: Required -> Windows 10 Enterprise is included, not Pro?
Office: Not Required
Windows Server: Required, A Windows Server is not part of MS365
Exchange: Not required

comments.content: Forgive me if Im wrong but my understanding is that the windows server is needed on premise to run Exchange (Exchange is installed on it). So when you migrate to 365 then you wont need that server anymore as exchange is included in the package?

discussion.content:
Absurd question even absurd answers

O365 infra means you dont need Windows server or Exchange. Windows 10 you need but that doesn't come under O365. Office professional if they have then equivalent 365 license required.

comments.content:
sorry :)
You need to determine which products require the purchase of Microsoft 365 licenses for new employees. - this the crucial question

discussion.content: You need to determine which products require the purchase of Microsoft 365 licenses for new ehttps://www.examtopics.com/exams/microsoft/ms-900/view/15/#mployees. - this the crucial question
what is the correct answer?

I would say

Windows 10 Pro -> Required since Windows 10 is part of M365
Office Professional -> Not Required
Server -> Not required
Exchange Client -> Required

https://www.microsoft.com/en-sg/microsoft-365/compare-microsoft-365-enterprise-plans

discussion.content: All wrong!!! Required/Not required/Not required/Not required

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
A company is investigating cloud solution provider (CSP) pricing models for Microsoft cloud services.
Match each CSP pricing model to its definition.
Instructions: To answer, drag the appropriate CSP pricing model from the column on the left to the definition on the right. Each CSP pricing model might be used once, more than once, or not at all.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

HOTSPOT -
Instructions: For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
YNY is correct since you can find Microsoft Entra (formerly Azure AD) roadmap on Microsoft 365 roadmap website. 

https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=%5B%22Microsoft+Entra%22%5D
YNN. Azure AD (Microsoft Entra ID) has it own roadmap in Azure, not M365
YNY is correct.
